text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- A real estate firm evicted a family from their apartment without a court order.

- Oil terminal owner Endel Siff accused the foreign ministry of unwillingness to improve relations with Russia. The ministry rejected the accusations and explained that Russia does not want better relations.
- Swedish police prevented an attempt to smuggle 14 Indians to Sweden in the luggage compartment of a tour bus.
- Justice Minister Paul Varul declared that the abolition of capital punishment as demanded by the EU can take place in two years but not earlier.
- Estonia is the third country in Eastern/Central Europe in terms of the level of foreign investment, Foreign Investments Agency director Juri Sakkeus announced.

- The President of the International Red Cross Committee, Cornelio Sommaruga, is visiting Estonia. He held a lecture on humanitarian law in Tartu University and stated that the Red Cross will have to restore its reputation after Soviet occupation.
- The fire in the Oru peat fields in northeastern Estonia has been reduced from 250 to 150 hectares, but winds may still spread the fire.
- The first parties have begun their election campaign for the local councils and the Reform Party intends to use 1.5 million kroons for campaigning.
- Prime Minister Tiit Vaehi opened a new cargo ferry line between Tallin and Kiel yesterday.
